It’s a tie between this and building for Shield Gauntlet Style. Both cost feats and money.

 

Light Shield (metal or wood): don’t bother, it’s worse than the buckler in almost every way possible.

 

Quickdraw Light Shield: if you intend on switching between using a shield and not, I’d probably still tell you to take Shield Gauntlet Style or a Buckler, but this item can be seen as a cheaper way to deal with the issue.

 

Heavy Shield (metal or wood): this is your mainstay for shields, since nothing really is better than it without building for it specifically. It’s the best one to use as a weapon, and it’s the best one to use for defense. There’s a specific item, the Mithral Heavy Shield that comes from Ultimate Equipment and answers the question on how to make one of these mithral, which I recommend unless you’re staying away from metal in which case look at Darkwood.

 

Tower Shield: you’re the only class that is proficient with these, rejoice. Thanks to that, you may actually consider building around one of these. Great defensive bonuses, but you still need feats to be able to function in combat properly when using one of these. Consider it for power turtles.

Throwing Shield: you can spend the money to add this to unclasp it as a free action. Quickdraw shields just became obsolete. Still, I wouldn’t consider it for an actual weapon as there is a class built for that.

 

Boss, Breakaway: for that one ratfolk build? It enables melee damage with splash weapons so you can consider it for anyone who wants to shield bash as well, adding some nice damage options for certain enemies with weaknesses.

 

Boss, Hooked: this allows you to do a trip attack to cause your enemy to become flat-footed (not prone). If you’re building a maneuver monkey and already don’t provoke when you trip this can be an amazing addition to your options.

 

Boss, Illuminating: generally you will not want to spend money on this, since light is a cantrip and an orison you’ll probably have someone on your team to deal with this anyway. That said, a sunrod does light better than most other ways so if it’s a necessity to your team you should consider it.

 

Boss, Reinforcing: if you are concerned about you shield being sundered or broken, one of these can help, though they are mostly extraneous.

Armor Modifications (Adventurer’s Armory 2)

[metal] Burnished: dazzled sucks.

 

Deflecting: I wouldn’t bother wasting a feat for a situational +1, but that’s just me. There are better options.

 

Double-Plated: if you’re running one of those builds that really doesn’t care about adding DEX to your AC, then this is for you. You will have to waste a feat though, if you’re using heavy armor as a base.

 

Jarring: the DC scales at a pretty decent rate, but sickened is a terribly weak condition to waste your money on.

 

Nimble: I was wondering when and how we’d get an equivalent to the 3.5 version of this. Only thing is, this is better! Enjoy having higher DEX, and if you want better armor too take the feat. Great for anyone who cares about maxing out that DEX/AC ratio.

 

Razored: you get better armor spikes, but you lose speed. Unless you’re a dwarf. Dwarves continue to get nice things. They use your armor’s enhancement bonus for their weapon enhancement bonus. If you take nothing else, take this.

 

Slumbering: you can now buy the Endurance feat, or improve you’re already existing Endurance feat. If your DM cares about this, take it.

 

Vitalguard: gives you +2 AC to enemy confirmation rolls. Not bad, probably worth losing 5ft of speed. Again, dwarves need not give a damn.

Special Materials

Abyssium (AP 61- Shards of Sin): immune to poison? Then avoid this at all costs. If you are immune to poison, go wild.

 

Adamantine: holy expensive! Weapons made from this have great uses, and I pretty much always make sure to pick one up. Armor grants you DR, which can stack with armored juggernaut. Are you building for DR? Get heavy armor made from this. Figure out the money later, it’s worth it. Also crafting technically reduces the cost to a third, as generally that’s considered the cost of the raw materials.

 

Angelskin: if you want to make one of those non-metal armors, this can help mask an evil alignment and protect you from things like Smite or Detect Evil. Niche utility, but an important one when it comes up.

 

Blood Crystal: probably one of the most metal materials on here, ironically it isn't even metal. If you’re building around a bleed build, like with Bleeding Critical and what not, then this is the material for you. Everyone else can skip it.

 

Darkleaf Cloth: I’m really glad this carried over from 3.5. It’s mithral for non-metal armors, so you can get some nice things going. It’s also relatively cheap as far as special materials go. It doesn’t reduce movement classification, but you shouldn’t really care because fighter.

 

Darkwood: this material is great for wooden shields, as it also functions just like mithral. There’s no rules for making armor out of this material, but I did have some fun with the idea a while ago, feel free to check that out.

 

Dragonhide (CRB & Dragon Slayer’s Handbook): I really wish I could cite the cool stuff from 3.5 that one could do with dragon corpses, but alas I cannot in this guide. In Dragon Slayer’s, it got a buff in being able to reduce the cost of energy resistance by 25%. Not as good as Dragoncraft Armor, but then again it really can’t be. It’s better for druids tbh.

 

Dragonskin (Dragon Slayer’s Handbook): this cannot make any armor, but it can make a decent grip for a weapon to help with being disarmed. Seems cool enough to add onto your main weapon, but is nowhere near essential.

 

Eel Hide: this material isn’t as good as Darkleaf, but it has some interesting properties. You can make all the leather armors out of it, so you can get some studded leather with reduced ACP and a slightly higher max DEX. You also randomly get electricity resistance 2, for games where that matters a lot.

 

Elysian Bronze: Adamantine that is specialized for monstrous humanoids and magical beasts to be your enemy. If you’re in a game where that’s the case, buy this over Adamantine every time, otherwise it’s just plain inferior.

 

Fire/Frost- Forged Steel: small little boosts like these are really nice in random loot situations. A suit of armor made from one of these grants energy resistance 2, which I believe could be enough to mitigate the damage from environments that Endure Elements otherwise covers. Fire is better thanks to the lack of nonmagical cold damage in enough bursts to gain damage, but otherwise a set of weapons and armor of these can be great in games where the environment matters. The rules are iffy, so check with your DM before assuming this material will protect you.

 

Greenwood: this is great for bows or other mostly wooden weapons that you want to make sure don’t break. Granted, most of the time this is a rare bookkeeping chore that most DMs don't enforce so it may be useless aside from the cool factor.

 

Griffon Mane: getting a cloak or something made of this can give you a small bonus on fly checks, which may or may not be relevant to you at later levels. It’s fairly cheap so it’s worth mentioning, but not essential.

 

Horacalcum (AP 61- Shards of Sin): this material is insane. Mad expensive, but it gives you a +1 circumstance to hit with weapons and a scaling bonus to initiative based on the size category of the armor. The cost is enough to dock it though, at least on armor.

 

Inubrix (AP 61- Shards of Sin): what an interesting material! You’ll have to figure out something for the damage dice, but you get to bypass certain metal armors completely. Worth it for certain scenarios.

 

Cold Iron: It’s here because it bypasses some DR, but i has no benefits for armor and it just adds costs to weapons. Maybe grab a weapon like this in games where fey and demons show up, but otherwise pass.

 

Living Steel: much like Greenwood, this material may or may not be entirely useful depending on your games. Armor made of this material gives enemies a reason to fear Nat 1’s which can be cool, but rare.

 

Mithral: you should already know what this is, as it’s ripped pretty much straight from Tolkein. Most people who aren’t sure about what to get their armor made from go for this, as it improves your DEX, speed for anyone that doesn’t have armor training 2 yet, and reduces ACP. Cost is high, but worth it. It also counts as silver for DR bypassing, nice!

 

Noqual (AP 61- Shards of Sin): super mithral for you. This stuff includes a free +2 resistance bonus against spells for armor, and gains an additional bonus against constructs and undead created by magic. You can’t cast spells, but you really don’t care. Generally though, you’re gonna be better off just paying for mithral because of the price point.

 

Siccatite (AP 61- Shards of Sin): this seems like an upgrade to Fire/Frost- Forged Steel, but it has a few differences. You get to just use the energy all the time, but you also take damage all the time. If you plan on using this (which you might) make sure you are playing a race that has or otherwise have the ability to gain energy resistance to the type of energy this armor gives off. It’s fairly cheap as well, which is nice. It also includes energy resistance 5 of the other type.

 

Alchemical Silver: for special materials, this one is a cheap way to get past DR. The weapons themselves aren’t that great because you take a -1 on damage rolls anyway, so only grab it if you absolutely need it now, or use some Silversheen (Qadira, Gateway to the East) instead.

 

Glaucite (AP 61- Shards of Sin): an alloy of iron and Adamantine, this metal really only offers better hardness and hp/inch than iron. I also can’t find a price for it, so probably don’t use it.

 

Viridium: gross, this stuff is poisonous to carry and the benefits of using it as a weapon don’t really matter for a DC 12 Fort save.

 

Whipwood: the Vanara race has a cool unique material to them which enhances wooden weapons like bows. It’s great to have the added HP and resistance to Sunder, though it may not come up in your games much.

 

Wyroot: this only works on builds that use an arcane pool or ki, which isn’t you. Even then it’s mediocre.

 

Alchemical Items

You will find these among the most useful of the mundane and nonmagical equipment you can pick up. They cover a large variety of uses, from utility to damage so be sure to note what you need on your character specifically.

 

[light] Liquid Blade: not a fan, of poisons or this weapon. Better on a different build.

 

[one-handed] Flame Fountain Firework: this is a really cool item, and if you fight things a lot that you need fire damage against (like trolls, or specific colored dragons) then carrying one of these can be useful, but they are mad expensive for the level(s) at which they are useful.

 

[splash] Acid: the most generic alchemical weapon you will find, and it’s pretty solid. You may want some to deal with trolls, or need some to deal with other enemies that need to be hit with acid to die. Fairly cheap as well.

 

[splash] Alchemist’s Fire: this costs twice as much as acid, but oftens serves the same purposes, and is a little better. If you have to pick between this and a flask of acid, pick this. For any alchemical weapon user this is your go-to weapon for the best price to effect ratio. Lighting things on fire is an important ability.

 

[splash] Alkali Flask: a straight upgrade to a regular flask of acid, this also greatly helps get rid of oozes, which you hate. This is the other go-to alchemical weapon.

 

[ranged touch] Bottled Lightning: very few other ways to get electricity damage, and this seems cool, but your abilities on your builds tend to focus more on splash weapons. If you need electricity (you probably won’t, but who knows) then pick some up, but stick to the better splash weapons if you need alchemical weapons.

 

[splash] Burst Jar: take away the caster’s turn(s)! Always take away the caster’s turn(s)! The damage is only secondary to a guaranteed deafen for at least 1 round, a possible stun, or forcing them to spend a whole turn avoiding it, thus a turn not casting.

 

[splash] Fuse Grenade: time lapse weapons are bad, you gotta hold onto it for 2 rounds then throw it. Ewwwwwwww.

 

[splash] Holy Water: fighting undead? This can help, a little. It’s better at lower levels when the undead can actually die from low amounts of area damage.

 

 

 

[balm] Holy Weapon Balm: fighting undead? This can help, A LOT. Each one of these is expensive (30gp a shot), but they can really add to your ability to land hits since they can treat your weapon as magical if it isn't already, and it can add 2d4 to your weapon’s attack. They are once and done kind of things on melee weapons, which means you waste a lot of time with them (standard action) but it’s better than the alternative when dealing with enemies that you need this for. Incorporeal enemies are game enders. Amazing on ammunition. Use at low levels.

 

[ranged touch] Keros Oil: do not swallow oil, do not try and spit out oil with a terrible range increment that does less damage than Alchemist’s Fire.

 

[splash] Liquid Ice: like Alchemist’s Fire, but twice as much and it does cold damage. Solid for what it does, but expensive.

 

[splash] Pellet Grenade: a very nice (and somehow cheaper?) upgrade to the fuse grenade, but it’s still a fuse grenade so you have the timing issue. Price is better too, and you have options to get over DR.

 

[splash] Flash Powder: Fort 13 is not that reliable, even at low levels.

 

[splash] Itching Powder: it stacks with debuffs like shaken or sickened, but the DC is only 12. Don’t bother.

 

[splash] Sneezing Powder: see itching powder.

 

[splash] Shard Gel: piercing damage with a splash weapon is pretty cool. Great if you need generic damage because things become immune to energy damage at later levels.

 

[splash] Tangleburn Bag: these are REALLLYYY expensive for what they do, but what they do is amazing, not only can they entangle an enemy with an amazing Reflex DC (25) but they also do fire damage. If going with alchemical weapons this is not one to miss.

 

[splash] Tanglefoot Bag: super useful if you ever want to hinder an enemy and not kill them, great for intrigue campaigns or intrigue like moments where you need to keep someone alive. It can also slow down spellcasters.

 

[ranged touch] Thunderstone: creates a deafening bang. DC is only 15, so it becomes pretty not useful once you get a few levels in.

 

Magic Items

There’s a great number of magic items in the game to consider, and a great number of magical abilities to attain. I can’t pretend to own every book or that I am all knowing when it comes to certain items being useful, there’s also the issues with errata coming out that changes certain things. Be aware of these and be careful when shopping with your DM as “Magic Mart” is not always available and choosing to build around certain magic items may hurt you more than it helps.

Magic Weapons

Remember that with all the abilities listed here, if you have the Warrior Spirit Advanced Weapon Training, then any and all of these are available to you on the fly, regardless of money or time. Consider this when you look into what abilities are worth investing into, and what abilities are better to grab mid combat. I’ll try and make a note of any situational differences in the description text, expect the rating to be based on its value to invest into, and any change in its rating based on Warrior Spirit to be listed in the description.

+1 Abilities

Agile (AP 100: A song of Silver): DERP. This is awesome, because slashing/fencing/starry grace isn’t. This ability is amazing, because DEX to damage.

 

Allying: I only really see one use of this, and it’s munchkin city. If you can manage to get a single weapon (like a gauntlet or helmet) that you will always have on you to +5 (or however high you want to get) you can keep that weapon equipped and target yourself as the ally to use this weapon with, meaning you can golfbag weapons without fear. Think of it as a really expensive way to cast Greater Magic Weapon.

 

Bane: this depends on your campaign a lot. If you find yourself fighting one type of enemy a lot, like undead or dragons, then nab this early as it’s essential to pumping those numbers up. Otherwise it is really high on the shortlist of Warrior Spirit options, if neither of those things are true, then this becomes rather situational.

 

Beaming (Blood of Shadows): WOW, once per day you get to shoot Searing Light at things, cool thing is it’s already CL 10th so it’s maxed out on damage and it only gets better as you increase your weapon’s enhancement bonus. Nice.

 

Benevolent: if you are using the familiar or teamwork builds that abuse aid another then pick this up, otherwise avoid it.

 

Bewildering (Dirty Tactics Toolbox): this is okay, DC 17 isn’t that bad but Will is not the save to target.

Blood-Hunting: it’s not Magebane. It can be a nice alternative if you are in a game where there’s a lot of sorcerers, but that’s really niche and since we’re talking niche this is gonna most likely fall into Warrior Spirit realms of usefulness.

 

Bloodsong: you’re not a bard, skald, or barbarian, just get keen.

 

Brawling: on its own it’s not that amazing, but remember when I talked keeping a gauntlet on? This is a great ‘always on’ ability for said gauntlet, but it’s redundant with Defending and not as strong.

 

Breaking (Dungeoneer’s Handbook): cool when fighting the one thing that it works against….

 

Called: I love this ability, I love it a lot. If you want to avoid Quickdraw as a feat, or end up in a situation where you need to get your weapon back from somewhere across the plane, then accept no other options.

 

Compassionate (Champions of Purity): this one is actually the best option for bringing someone back alive. You get to control it with a free action, and you can automatically stabilize someone with your weapon so long as they aren’t “dead, dead”. Great to pick up situationally.

 

Conductive: the fighter class has nothing to use this with, so unless you are multiclassing or have a racial ability, pass on this.

 

[ranged] Conserving: I actually really like this, though it seems a bit less than stellar compared to Endless Ammunition, even at the lower (and much more desirable) bonus cost.

 

Corrosive: the first of many elemental damages available to you. All of these are just okay, but some are more important than others, and this is one of them since there is less acid resistance in the books than there is of any other element, and there are some enemies that need acid or fire to kill them this one stands out as one of the best elements for damage.

CHEESE DISCLAIMER: I’ve seen players cheese their way into putting multiple elements on their weapons at the same time, arguing with the DM that as long as they all trigger off the same command word that they can all be active at the same time and you can stack the damage up. Doesn’t work in my games, but for the sake of the guide I must mention this ‘strategy’ to you.

 

[melee] Countering: this is a very situational one, as you often will not find too many enemies that want to disarm or sunder you in most books. Thanks to that Warrior Spirit though, it can have situational usefulness.

 

Courageous: fear saves, ughhhh. The other ability I believe has been clarified to only enhance the morale bonus on fear effects, but if you go by RAW then it works on all of them, like Flagbearer which makes it worth mentioning.

 

Cruel: not sure how this works on ranged weapons, but it does. Great for intimidate monsters that want that little extra umph, but hardly necessary.

 

Cunning: this one has the same situational usefulness as bane, but gated by skill access. But eventually getting a +6 untyped bonus to confirm crits that stacks with Critical Focus is good.

 

Dazzling Radiance (Dirty Tactics Toolbox): Dazzling Display is awesome and all, and a DC 17 Fort save seems okay at lower levels. This ability tatters out in usefulness, though granted combining dazzled with shaken can be a pretty nice debuff (-3 on attacks) at those lower levels.

 

[melee] Deadly: avoid whips, avoid saps, avoid this.

 

Debilitating (Spymaster’s Handbook): it’s not useless, but it’s definitely better on an Unchained Rogue.

 

Deceptive (Pathfinder Society Primer): if you’re building a bluff-feint build then this is a no-brainer choice otherwise skip it.

 

Defending: CHEESE ALERT- this ability is great in some very specific scenarios. I love to grab a helmet, or spiked gauntlet that has a bunch of ‘always on’ effects, and this is one of them. By ‘sacrificing’ your last iterative attack each round, you can choose to attack with whatever weapon you have currently available, and you can spend your bottom attack (that usually isn’t going to hit anyway) to instead boost your AC with a weapon that you don’t care about losing that attack bonus. This works wonders for Power Turtles.

 

Dispelling: are you building the Anti-Mage? This helps you do that better, since Shatter Spell and the like all function similarly (if not directly referenced to) Spell Sunder. A caster friend dumping scrolls of Dispel Magic into your weapon that you pay for can be an awesome way to build up your anti-casting repertoire.

 

[ranged] Distance: on its own, I feel this works better on thrown ranged weapons that you intend to have come back to you. Most bows have decent range on their own anyway.

 

[ranged] Driving (Weapon Master’s Handbook): Bull Rush or Trip with your ranged weapons. Seems cool, too bad both maneuvers aren’t that great for ranged style.

 

Fervent (Quests & Campaigns): like worshipping oddball gods? This is a cool little ability that can add to improve your critical confirmations against anyone who doesn’t worship your god. Most of the other stuff won’t come up.

 

Flaming: it’s just as useful as acid, but a LOT more things are fire resistant (hence immune to this) which causes this to have a lower rating than acid.

 

[melee] Fortuitous: !!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! Extra attacks of opportunity are awesome!!!!!!!! Aptly named.

 

Frost: while it doesn’t have as many uses as fire or acid, it still has uses.

 

Ghost Touch: if you will fight incorporeal enemies a lot, then buy the crap out of this! If not, then make a note of it for when you might need it with Warrior Spirit. Otherwise, they still have a 50% miss chance just because.

 

Grayflame: you don’t channel, do you?

 

[melee] Grounding: it’s like a worse bane against air-subtypes. Even with Warrior Spirit there are better choices.

 

[melee] Growing (Melee Tactics Toolbox): I like this a lot, but it’s only 1/day. That said, this can really drive home some damage on the Vital Strike builds that really want those higher damage dice. It’s unclear how this interacts with Impact or other effects which actually enlarge you, so be sure to double check with your DM before you pay for this.

 

Guardian: it’s Defending, but for saves. Ironically, your author has a dairy allergy and thus cannot enjoy cheese.

 

[melee] Heartseeker: super situational, but in those situations man is it good. Grab with Warrior Spirit, if anything.

 

Huntsman: I guess it helps with survival checks? Even rangers don’t tend to bother with this, and it’s worse than Bane.

 

[bladed] Injecting (Agents of Evil): this works better on rogues or other classes that focus on poisons.

 

[piercing or slashing] Keen: Improved critical, now available at level 5 thanks to Warrior Spirit! Good ability is good. If you are at higher levels it actually might be worth taking the feat to get more cool abilities on your weapon, but hey what do I know?

 

Kinslayer (Quests & Campaigns): I don’t think the Adam & Eve argument works to justify this working against your entire race, so this is the most situational. Just get Bane…

 

[melee]  Leveraging (Weapon Master’s Handbook): if you’re building for these specific maneuvers, then this is pretty good. That said the maneuvers this works with wane in usefulness at higher levels making it hard to justify paying for.

 

Limning: wow this is one of the most situational abilities. Thanks to Warrior Spirit, that’s your schtick!

 

Menacing: normally this is just alright, but if you have one of those special builds that abuses a familiar, teamwork feats, or an animal companion this becomes a non-decision.

 

Merciful: wow, no one likes to make a weapon permanently non-lethal. Sure you can turn it off, but that’s still a +1 that you gotta pay for. Unless of course, you can just choose to have this ability at any time that is convenient, if only I had some way to do that…. It can save you feats, and add to your damage this way, making it a great situational buff.

 

Mighty Cleaving: the most situational ability to use with a very situational feat. Bleh.

 

[melee] Mimetic: my brain hurts from thinking of all the scenarios in which this is useful, of which there are a lot. A lot of stuff has energy resistance, but you gotta consider how often those energy types will get thrown right back at you. Against dragons or outsiders this seems like a no brainer, which puts this into a situationally good place.

 

Miserable (Agents of Evil): on its own this is pretty bad, but if you are in a team that needs to get around ER, then grabbing this on the fly can really help out your other teammates like the blaster wizard. Support role for the fighter, neat.

 

[melee] Neutralizing: it’s Grounding, but for Earth, and just as bad for the same reasons.

 

[melee] Ominous: Intimidate overkill, though adding second chances to inflict the shaken condition if they somehow withstand Dazzling Display can be a nice backup plan. Best used on intimidate builds with Warrior Spirit who need a second chance.

 

Patriotic (Quests & Campaigns): I don’t like this, the buffs it gives aren’t really that great in combat and a DC 13 save to give the shaken condition is subpar.

 

Planar: against outsiders, ignore 5 more points of DR. Do you fight outsiders often? If yes then buy this, if not then write it down for Warrior Spirit. You seem to need to do a lot of bookkeeping…

 

[melee] Quenching: Grounding, but for fire. Can’t even do anything cool with it….

 

[ranged] Returning: there’s a bunch of ways to get this without having to pay for it, so before you do I would consider those options. The main option would be to grab this with Warrior Spirit until you have enough feats to get the better versions of this ability on your own.

 

[melee] Seaborne: super useful underwater, which is entirely campaign dependent. I hear there’s an AP or two that is works wonders in though, otherwise it’s great to nab with Warrior Spirit.

 

[ranged] Seeking: You need it.

 

[projectile ranged] Shadowshooting (Blood of Shadows): this is everything Endless Ammunition should be. It’ll have anywhere from a DC 16-22 Will save, depending on what all else you have going on, but your damage should be coming from flat bonuses and not a reliance on dice. If you really want to not worry about ammunition, this is the answer. Does it reload the weapon without requiring an action? It’s unclear so there’s no real answer on whether or not this adds some level of viability to the crossbow (probably not).

 

Shock: as far as elemental damage goes, a bunch of things are resistant to electricity, and almost nothing is weak to it. It’s the worst of all of them, but not useless.

 

[bludgeoning melee] Smashing (Melee Tactics Toolbox): honestly, it’s only on this list because I wanted to make a Nigel Thornberry joke. Then I realized no one cares, unless you really care about sundering items.

 

Spell Storing: it’s generally not worth investing the resources to fake the spellcasting needed to make one of these work. Something like UMD on a wand of a 10d6 Shocking Grasp or similar combat buff seems appropriate, but not good. Maybe on the Child of Acavna and Amaznen build.

 

[melee] Thawing: Grounding for ice, but it can melt ice as long as it’s medium or smaller, so in those cases I guess it’s as good as a utility spell if you want to grab it with Warrior Spirit.

 

[melee] Throwing: why spend the money on magic to add a 10ft range to your weapon when you can just use a weapon designed for it?

 

Thundering: on crits you get to add a d8 of sonic damage and they can roll a DC 14 (lol) fort save to avoid becoming deaf. To get more damage, you have to use a weapon that won’t crit as often and you’re better off grabbing something that does more damage more often.

 

*-* Training *-* (Inner Sea Intrigue): dear me, what an enhancement. Are you lacking a feat? Do you want to grab a feat in a pinch with Warrior Spirit? This is the most important ability on this list. It is unclear how this works with itself, meaning that I’m not sure if you can place this on a weapon multiple times like you can with Bane. Most sane DMs will say no. If you really want some cheese, get some gauntlets or some armor spikes that you’ll have always equipped to grab some feats that you otherwise don’t wanna waste feat slots on. You can’t use it for prerequisites, so make sure it’s either a feat that isn’t part of a chain, or is at the end of one.

 

Valiant: since I brought up the cavalier VMC earlier, it’s here for them and it’s great for them.

 

[piercing or slashing melee] Vampiric (Horror Adventures): damage you deal can heal you up to 2x your level per day. I’d hold out for the Greater version.

 

[ranged] Veering (Ranged Tactics Toolbox): reduce soft cover and partial cover by 2. Situational, but good.

 

Vicious: if you have a build that can circumvent the damage somehow (how does my own DR interact with this?), like with self healing, then this is amazing, otherwise you don’t want to cause harm to yourself more than you have to.

+2 Abilities

[melee] Advancing: it’s meh. For a +2 ability, you still have to waste an action to make a 5-foot step. Still, mobility matters.

 

Anarchic: entirely campaign dependent, the alignment based enhancements vary from being amazing to useless. This one probably falls closer to the bottom thanks to the predisposition of most published APs.

 

[melee or thrown] Anchoring: wanna make Thor’s Hammer? This is how you make Thor’s Hammer. It’s situational, but you can create that situation for yourself.

 

Axiomatic: Slightly above Anarchic thanks to the common nature of enemies in APs, but still situational.

 

Corrosive Burst: I highly dislike wasting an extra +1 on a burst ability, because it is entirely dependent on crits landing, and at that it’s still not gonna give you that much more damage since it adds only a single d10 most of the time. Otherwise it becomes less and less reliable to access more damage. Poor design.

 

[slashing melee] Culling: do you have Cleave or Great Cleave? Add 2d6 when you use it. It also works on Cleaving Finish or Greater Cleaving Finish.

 

[ranged] Cyclonic: $%&@ your Wind Wall! It also works underwater.

 

[melee] Defiant: what fun this is! You no longer drop your weapon under fear conditions, and you get to add its enhancement bonus to saves vs. nasty things that you want to add things to. It also gives you more uses of the Heroic feats, nice!

 

[ranged] Designating, Lesser: it’s good for a party buff on the BBEG, but I would hold out for greater.

 

Dispelling Burst: it can hold greater dispel magic? AND it gets to do a bunch more other cool stuff? I’m sold, take my money.

 

[bludgeoning melee] Disruption: I’m not a fan of any bludgeoning weapon that isn’t a dire flail, and 14 is a really low DC considering this is a +2 ability, and thus not available to you until way after that low a DC is useless.

 

[bows and crossbows] Endless Ammunition: I’m torn on this one. Money says that overall this isn’t worth it, unless you can get it so early that you can literally track all the money you save on mundane arrows. Take it if you don’t wanna keep track of arrows.

 

Flaming Burst: see- Corrosive Burst.

 

[melee] Furyborn: if I’m paying for a +2 enhancement, then why am I not just upgrading the total weapon by +2 and not wasting 2 attacks on maybe getting this to work? Ewww

 

[ranged] Glitterwake: free glitterdust 3/day. Really situational, but never useless. Perfect for Warrior Spirit.

 

[melee] Glorious: I like the Daylight effect, because it’s awesome. But you can’t turn it off and again, DC 14 is not that great of a save to force. Still, you will note it for any character that doesn’t have Darkvision for Warrior Spirit.

 

Heretical: bane vs. a specific religion. Like bane, this works great for Warrior Spirit.

 

Holy: of all the alignment enhancements you can get, this is the one that is worth the money. Unless you’re in an evil campaign, then don’t use it.

 

Icy Burst: I’ll give you two guesses why this is red…

 

Igniting: Everyhting that Flaming Burst wishes it could be. You force enemies to make a save or waste an action to put themselves out or they keep burning every round. This is how you upgrade an elemental weapon.

 

[NOT LIGHT melee] Impact: this is fun, depending on what weapon you’re using. If you have the Focused Weapon ability this becomes a no-brainer. It’s also one of the best ways to make me care about Vital Strike. It’s also good for Bull Rush builds.

 

[melee] Invigorating: well, it seems that combat stamina thing just got a new toy. If you plan on dropping enemies ever (you do) then this will either restore the fatigued condition, or give you a +2 on attack rolls and a +10ft movement speed. Good ability is good.

 

[bludgeoning melee] Legbreaker: reduce the enemies speed, or force them to waste an action. Doesn’t stop them from moving, but can be useful in a chase I guess?

 

[melee] Liberating (Ultimate Intrigue): this gives you an enhancement bonus on Sense Motive checks, and doubles that bonus to check for enchantments. It also switches over to nonlethal to help free someone from an enchantment spell. Plus it’ll give that person an extra chance to save. Niche utility, but good niche to have, Warrior Spirit this.

 

[melee] Lifesurge: if you plan on fighting a lot of undead, or otherwise are facing a lot of nasty necromancy effects, this is the best option you’re gonna get. Even if you aren’t, keep it in your bag of Warrior Spirit tricks. It’ll also give you a slight boost on Temp HP.

 

Negating: this is very situational, but when you need it, you effing need it. It helps the whole party for a round, which is great. Warrior Spirit is such a nice thing.

 

[ammunition] Penetrating (Magical Marketplace): shoot an arrow through someone into another someone. If you have one of those infinitely lasting arrows, this is okay but otherwise not worth money.

 

Phase Locking: another incredibly situational ability for Warrior Spirit.

 

[bludgeoning melee] Quaking (Weapon Master’s Handbook): wanna make a trip build work better? This gives you an area attack to trip. I hate bludgeoning weapons, but if you’re going the Maneuver Monkey route this makes a good case for them.

 

[melee or thrown] Sharding (Weapon Master’s Handbook): OMG sword beams!!!!!!!! It’s range is only 10 ft, but I’m sure you have ways around that. Get you a Belt of Mighty Hurling and the Far Shot feat.

 

Shattering (Dungeoneer’s Handbook): upgraded Breaking enchantment. Still not that good.

 

Shocking Burst: plz stahp

 

Silencing (Ultimate Intrigue): amazing for subterfuge, so if that’s your thing, spend all your money on this. Otherwise, pass.

 

Stalking: you’re not a slayer, rogue, assasin, or stalker vigilante? Forget this.

 

Toxic (Agents of Evil): increase Poison DC by 2, and you have a 25% chance to use that dose of poison twice; good I guess for that ratfolk build?

 

Treasonous (Quests & Campaigns): it works like a Patriotic weapon, but it’s also bane against either that nation, or ethnicity. It’s 2017 now so any joke I had planned for this is no longer going to be funny, fill in the blanks.

 

[melee] Truthful (Ultimate Intrigue): I love it, it bypasses displacement, blur, mirror image, and even invisibility if you know which square to attack. It also functions like a Dispelling weapon against certain types of illusions.

 

Unholy: replace everything in Holy’s description mentioning alignment with its opposite. Great for evil games where you play villains fighting good, which I don’t think is often.

 

Unseen (Ultimate Intrigue): it reminds me of the enhancements for rogue’s in 3.5. Too bad you’re not a rogue and to use this properly you need Blind-Fight. Meh.

 

[melee] Vampiric (Weapon Master’s Handbook): different from the aforementioned +1 ability, this one can heal you up to three times per day with up to 2d6. Not worth a +2.

 

[piercing or slashing melee] Vampiric, Greater (Horror Adventures): heal up to 5x your level per day from this thing. Not bad.

 

[melee] Wounding: bleed damage is great against enemies who aren’t immune, it causes them to coninuously take more and more damage the more you hit them with it. It also forces an action from them to get rid of it, which is good.

+3 Abilities

[melee] Exhausting: you can forgo a crit to instead inflict the exhausted condition. While it’s not as good as stunned, it’s still pretty great. I would still rather use a critical feat though.

 

[melee] Gory (Dirty Tactics Toolbox): it’s an upgraded Wounding, that does a d2 instead of just 1 bleed damage. Not great so far, but if you manage a crit with it, you can get an immediate action Intimidate check and get a bonus equal to your level. This appears to function even if the enemy is immune to bleed damage, great on intimidate builds.

 

[melee] Nullifying: this ability is largely useless to you, but if you spend the money on it your wizard friend will owe you forever, and having leverage over the wizard might be worth the money, maybe.

 

[melee] Repositioning: weak bonus on the reposition maneuver, but on a crit you can reposition as a free action. Definitely not worth the money.

 

Redeemed (Champions of Purity): did you find an Unholy weapon that you can’t use? Fear not for you can upgrade it into this, now it functions as a Holy weapon and has some nice benefits for fighting against evil outsiders. Niche, but good.

 

Speed: haste during a full round attack, but permanent! It’s the benchmark for just how good a +3 enhancement should be. If no one in your party can cast haste, consider it. Otherwise it really isn’t worth the money ehn there’s plenty of other things you can buy that your wizard can’t duplicate. If you need it, remember Warrior Spirit is a thing.

 

[melee] Spell Stealing: forgo critical threats to learn what buffs your enemy has and potentially steal one. This is a mixed bag, you may find it incredibly useful against enemy teams armed with spellcasters (of which there will be several), but actually making that CL check is going to largely be dependent on the d20 roll and you have to give up your crit to do it. I’m leaning toward no, since the biggest utility of this can be duplicated mostly by the Spellcraft skill mid combat by your allied casters.

 

[ranged] Tailwind (Ranged Tactics Toolbox): add a utility gust of wind spell to your arrows. This is only as useful as you can imagine it being, so if you can’t find a way to use it all the time, then definitely make a note of it for Warrior Spirit because it is FAR from useless.

 

 

[melee] Umbral (Ultimate Intrigue): did you have a problem obtaining darkvision? Well, as long as you hold onto this weapon’s hilt or handle you get darkvision 30. Not bad, it also has a darkness effect that can be used defensively which you are immune to thanks to the baked in darkvision and the weapon itself has concealment for things like sunder. Consider this useful.

+4 Abilities

 

Brilliant Energy: if you can get this early, it’s worth it, if not it may not be so. It works amazingly against humanoid enemies with class levels that wear armor, as it negates the bonus from armor and shields. If you’re fighting monsters that don’t wear armor then it becomes a huge waste of money. It also will take forever to get to work with Warrior Spirit, so figure out what kind of game you’re playing before you invest since the weapon won’t be doing much more than this thanks to the +4 rating.

 

[melee] Dancing: so this is really cool, but what in game benefits do you really get from it? 4 rounds of a free weapon attack seems cool, but I can’t find the part where you get to add your STR/DEX/whatever stat you use to hit for it; because you don’t. Skip this.

 

 

 

[ranged] Designating, Greater: woop woop! If you land a hit with your highest BAB attack, then the rest of the round you and all your allies get +4 to hit and +6 damage against that enemy. You count as your own ally, so unless you're getting a better morale bonus from someone else (probably not) then take all my money.

 

[ranged] Nimble Shot: did you want to completely avoid taking Point-Blank Master? Here you go. This seems better for characters that aren’t focused on ranged combat but instead are picking it up as a great secondary combat role. At +4, you really don't want to waste this on your primary weapon when Point-Blank Master is a thing.

 

[bows] Second Chance: once per round, reroll any attack you want. It’s so good, but so expensive at +4. I can’t endorse the money investment or wasting your + slots on this, I would rather invest your resources into not needing a second chance, no pun intended, probably.

+5 Abilities

[melee] Flying: it’s an upgraded Dancing that actually lets you flank with it. Great, if only you were a rogue that needed this…

 

[piercing ranged] Heart-Piercing (Weapon Master’s Handbook): it’s ranged Vorpal, bleh.

 

[ranged] Interfering (Ranged Tactics Toolbox): It’s like taking all the Snapshot feats at once, then doubling their range. If you want to go all in on having ranged AOOs then dump all your money on this because this is how we do it. You won’t be able to add in any other abilities though, unless you cheat.

 

[slashing melee] Vorpal: 5% of the time, it works every time; bleh.

Flat Cost Abilities

[composite bows; 1,000] Adaptive: your bow now changes to match your STR mod. Worth it, so, so worth it.

 

[finessable melee; 14,000] Dueling: +4 enhancement bonus to initiative, nice! Great to put on a gauntlet. Everyone should like this, you could even tack Training on the same weapon to give yourself Improved Initiative for added silliness.

 

[4,000] Glammered: make your warhammer look like an Umbrella! Kudos if you got that reference. It can be useful if you need to disguise your weapon, but it stops working the second you attack with it.

 

[3,000] Impervious: do you not ever want to worry about oozes or sundering? This is how you never have to worry about oozes or sundering.

 

[7,000] Liberating (Weapon Master’s Handbook): same name as another ability, but this one is worth all the money you can muster. You get to free yourself from paralysis, really? Paralysis, slow, web, or anything that restricts movement? TAKE MY MONEY.

 

[ammunition; 2,000] Phantom Ammunition: do you care about covering your tracks for an assassination?

 

[ranged projectile; 1,875; 7,500; 16,875] Sniping, Improved, & Greater (Ranged Tactics Toolbox): it is important to note that there is a different Sniping ability that’s specifically out there for rogues. Honestly this kinda is too. If you really plan on staying hidden for your attacks, this won’t eat up any +’s on your bow, but it doesn’t really seem necessary.

 

[melee; 10,000] Transformative: this can be a useful enhancement if you find some nice random loot in the form of a weapon other than the one you’re primarily trained with. You could also take the Advanced Weapon Training ability that allows all your weapon specific feats to apply to the whole weapon group and change your weapon into anything else you’ll need. Like a reach weapon, etc. Still, too expensive for not being that great. Unless you can also change weapon modifications, like in Adventurer’s Armory 2 or Weapon Master’s Handbook. Then it’s okay.

 

[15,000] Transformative, Greater (Inner Sea Intrigue): like the previous ability, however you can change your weapon freely into anything you want. Superior to the regular version in every way, it’s worth the extra 5,000 and having its own entry in this guide. Extra worth it if you can change weapon modifications.

Specific Weapons

[11,330] Axe of Felling (Giant Hunter’s Handbook): +1 giant bane dwarven waraxe that has the trip ability, it can trip foes up to two sizes larger.

 

[7,300] Beastrike Club: a +1 club that counts as a natural weapon, in case you wanted to try and make a build that relies on natural weapons (like the build that can get pounce).

 

[12,350] Blade of Binding: +1 greatsword that gives you a free action grapple check and a +5 untyped bonus to grapple that creature. Not bad if you wanna grapple.

 

[12,302] Constrictor’s Gauntlets (Dirty Tactics Toolbox): they’re on here because there’s rules that say gauntlets can’t be made into +1 weapons. Here’s a pair. Will save DC 16 isn’t that good and only works on enemies that wear armor.

 

[10,302] Dagger of Doubling: this has some utility uses as you can continue to spawn extra daggers to throw or use in case you didn't invest into the throwing feats to do it normally.

 

[26,340] Density Hammer (Elemental Master’s Handbook): +3 earth breaker, meh. But, it does prevent you from being petrified by reducing its enhancement by 1. So you can survive up to 3 petrifications per day, that’s useful and worth looking at if you fear petrification.

 

[30,320] Devil Catcher (Adventurer’s Guide): it’s a net that blocks teleportation, and also debuffs devils. Worth considering for the utility in capturing casters. Rather expensive though.

 

[17,820] Disarming Blade: a +1 Dueling Rapier that lets you kick an enemy’s weapon 5ft away after a disarm. Disarm isn’t that good.

 

[40,310] Dragon’s Doom: +2 dragonbane halberd that ignores a dragon’s DR already before applying its 3/day ability to ignore a dragon’s DR. Waste of ink.

 

[32,310] Dragon’s Tail (Dragonslayer’s Handbook): a +2 dragonbane guisarme that has a DC 20 Fortitude save (finally one that isn’t just awful) that staggers for 1 round. Not bad, works better against dragons, if you can get them to fail their save.

 

[13,308] Dragoncatch Guisarme: a +1 dragonbane guisarme that for some reason can try and trip a flying dragon, that’s already flying…

 

[25,312] Dwarfbond Hammer: it’s like Thor’s Hammer, sort of. You get a range of 20ft to throw it, and it otherwise functions as a +2 Returning Warhammer that does an extra d8 against giants. You have to be a dwarf though.

 

[60,312] Dwarven Thrower: it’s an upgreaded Dwarfbond Hammer, now it functions as a +3 Returning warhammer, and has a 30 foot range.

 

[14,350] Eagle’s Blade (People of the River): a +1 greatsword that can upgrade itself once you kill something with it into a +2 bane greatsword against the same type of creature for 8 rounds. I love it.

 

[11,315] Earthenflail: it’s magically adamantine, until you want to smash through cover made of earth. If the enemy is wearing stoneplate they’ll be extra upset. Nice in underground games that rely on cover, or can get you to do some silly things like smashing through metal handles on the other side of stone doors.

 

[2,500] Effortless Lace (Giant Hunter’s Handbook): don’t spend the feats or the Advanced Weapon Training! You can wrap this around any one-handed piercing or slashing weapon to turn it into a Finesse weapon.

 

[22,375] Fanged Falchion (Rise of the Runelords: Anniversary Edition): the best evil weapon you’re gonna find.

 

[7,315] Fighter’s Fork: a +1 trident that can change between being a reach two-hander or a finessable one-hander with a swift action. Trident feats apply to both forms. Talk about versatility.

 

[10,301] Fighting Tankard (Weapon Master’s Handbook): this is a drinking mug that not only functions as a weapon, but also works like a Handy Haversack with up to 6 different potions in your glass. Blade and Tankard style is really fun with this if you’re a potion guy or want to try some alchemy stuff.

 

[9,305] Fist of the Pit (Inner Sea Temples): it’s a spiked gauntlet that lets you cast a better version of spiked pit than a wizard. And it has rules for enhancing it more.

 

[20,715] Flame Tongue: a flaming burst longsword that can shoot one fire beam per day. Not worth your money.

 

[18,505] Fleshwarped Scorpion’s Tail (Magical Marketplace): a neat way to make a whip matter, it gets a neat little poison ability that sucks. But you can have this surgically implanted (right) to give yourself a natural sting attack and the poison then scales off your HD. Natural attack that comes magical, and a scaling DC. Make sure the DM is okay with poisons…

 

[54,475] Frost Brand: a +3 frost greatsword for when you really, really don’t like fire. Fire is okay though, sometimes.

 

[25,700] Frozen Crossbow (Ranged Tactics Toolbox): if you’re underwater, this is good. If not, it’s useless.

 

[35,312] Ghoul’s Lament: a +1 ghost touch disruption warhammer that can knock an undead prone by forcing a DC 20 Fortitude save. Most undead will have bad forts, this isn’t bad, in undead based games.

 

[8,810] Gloom Blade: a weapon specifically for when you’re in the dark. The darker it is, the better it gets, ultimately giving you Blind-Fight for free. Meh.

 

[4,370] Grafting Blade (Spymaster’s Handbook): need a weapon in a pinch? Instead of using an improvised weapon, this little blade can turn ordinary wooden objects into +1 weapons for you. Great backup weapon.

 

[3,805] Grasping Bolas (Giant Hunter’s Handbook): this is cool because you get to be like Batman! But these things have no HP and will die and be a waste of money way too easily.

 

[307] Grave Marker Arrow (Agents of Evil): DC 11 caster level check… This will only work in an open field where you’re running into what’s probably already relatively harmless (and thus not worth the extra investment) undead.

[65,310] Guarding Blade: this weapon will try and protect your corpse for 4 rounds before giving up. There might be something to this intelligent weapon idea, but that’s way too much DM talk for me.

 

[60,302] Hateful Sting (Inner Sea Temples): A dancing dagger that turns into a wasp and can deliver 4 poisons. It can also travel up to 60 feet, this seems more like a rogue/assassin thing.

 

[13,850] Headsman’s Blade: you get to assassinate people like a slayer, with a DC of 15. Bleh, it’s a slayer weapon for slayers. It is a +1 keen greatsword though.

 

[50,302] Heartswood Spear: +2 undead bane spear that can also apparently just do bludgeoning damage and gets disruption when it doers it. Not bad in undead campaigns, it gives you some versatility.

 

[22,325] Hooked Massacre (Horror Adventures): a spiked chain that functions as a reach weapon as a free action for a round. It’s still not as good as 3.5, but it’s cool. You’ll have to get proficiency for it.

 

[36,324] Hunter’s Starknife (Inner Sea Combat): a +2 wounding starknife that has the ability to embed itself into an opponent, forcing them to either continue taking bleed damage each round, or forcing them to take a full-round action to remove it. It can buy you an extra turn to move in and attack, but it is very expensive.

 

[547; 1,047] Hushing Arrow: Will DCs of 13 and 16 respectively trigger a silence spell when you successfully hit an opponent and they fail. Not a fan.

 

[1,500] Javelin of Lightning: a regular javelin that can become a DC 14 lightning bolt that doesn’t require a UMD check. If it had more utility I would be impressed, but these really don’t do much for you.

 

[5,220] Judicial Hammer (Champions of Balance): a DC 13 Will save to force someone to tell the truth seems like a waste of money, especially considering this is just a +1 earthbreaker.

 

[4,310] Lance of Jousting: you get a scaling DC to force an opponent to make a ride check or get knocked off their mount. If you think mounted enemies will be common, this isn’t worthless, though you’ll most likely want to go for a mounted build, which isn’t advised.

 

[15,715] Lizardmarked Blade (Magical Marketplace): you can detect electricity resistance, which might be cool, but seems pretty low utility. It’s a +1 shock gladius, but it can up its own damage by one step once per day.

 

 

[22,060; 62,360; 102,660; 142,960] Luck Blade: even if you can’t afford the the ones with the wishes in them, a free +1 Luck Bonus to AC and a reroll power are very nice especially considering the wording here is ‘possessor’ and not ‘wielder’ which I’m pretty sure means you can just carry this guy around as a backup weapon that gives you nice little bonuses, which makes this a comparable option with the Luckstone.

 

[50,312] Mace of Keys (Inner Sea Temples): this is really really expensive, but if you can manage a combat maneuver then you can knock off an opponent’s magic item from a key slot. The weapon isn’t that great though.

 

[16,012; 75,312] Mace of Smiting: the lesser version of this is a decent weapon to invest in if you think you’re going to fight constructs a lot. It’s decent against outsiders, but it functions as a +3 weapon against constructs which costs less than a +3 weapon normally. The greater version automatically destroys constructs on a crit, which has no save. I don't hate it, but it’s more or less vorpal vs. constructs and vorpal only works 5% of the time…

 

[38,552] Mace of Terror: DC 16 Will save effect, so not worth the extra money considering this is a +2 heavy mace.

 

[32,310] Mammoth Lance (Adventurer’s Guide): this weapon is amazing on small characters, it even makes gnomes playable. You get to use your mount’s STR in place of your own when mounted on an Animal. The Animal Ally feat, or Sylvan Bloodline can get you there. It’s a +2 lance, so it’s designed for mounted characters.

 

[28,312] Marrowcracker (Magical Marketplace): I really like this weapon’s effect, doing 1d4 STR or DEX damage on a crit, the problem is that it’s a +2 mighty cleaving warhammer. If you could get this on a better crit range, then I’d go for it.

 

[36,302] Mind’s Eye Blade (Ultimate Intrigue): this +2 dagger seems better for rogues, but gaining concealment nigh indefinitely is a pretty good benefit.

 

[32,870] Murderer’s Machete (Horror Adventures): I’m pretty sure the book says as long as you have this weapon, you have to use your Danny Trejo voice. It’s an evil weapon, a +1 keen short sword, but once per day it can give you a fear based buff spell that lets you teleport around the fear that you can detect. It says it functions like Dimension Door, so it may be compatible with Dimensional Agility, et. all. Great for intimidate builds.

 

[78,310] Greater Murderer’s Machete (Horror Adventures): it’s quite the jump in price, but now it’s +2 keen and wounding.

 

[12,700] Nightpiercer (Inner Sea Temples): a +1 repeating ghost touch heavy crossbow that halves the speed of any incorporeal undead it shoots for the turn.

 

[23,057] Nine Lives Stealer: for an evil weapon this sure is good. If you score a crit, they have to make a DC 20 Fort or die. It works 9 times, have fun with that!

 

[25,600] Oathbow: a +2 composite (2 STR) longbow that can give itself super bane against one enemy every day. You gotta kill the thing you’re targeting though, if an ally does it then it doesn’t count. It gives you a really strong weapon for a boss fight for less than half the cost of a normal weapon of +5 and bane. Also it talks.

 

[55,330] Pactseeker’s Blade (Blood of the Coven): a +2 cruel cold iron longsword that damages your opponent’s allies that are under the same shared spell effect, like haste or other team buffs. You damage the whole team, by the effective enhancement bonus. Nice group damage potential, on full rounds you can be dealing an extra 5-25 damage to each enemy, multiplying into a lot of damage overall.

 

[916] Phase Arrow (Ranged Tactics Toolbox): it’s almost like getting the Arcane Archer class ability, but it costs money. These arrows are so good, on a Seeking bow you’ll never have to worry about obstructions or cover. Expensive though.

 

[12,310] Polarity Hammer: this weapon has a lot of neat tricks, but it relies on your enemies either wearing metal armor or being made of metal, so it gets very campaign specific and you’d have to get proficiency to use it. It’s a +1/+1 meteor hammer.

 

[646] Prying Star (Ultimate Intrigue): a +1 single shuriken that has some great utility. If you hit a target with it, it can become an undetectable tracer for 9 minutes that you can follow by closing your eyes, like a little scrying effect.

 

[19,318] Purging Falcata (Inner Sea Combat): this is like a Heretical falcata on crack. If you went for the cavalier VMC build, this will have great use to you by gaining bane vs a specified religion. It’s also a +2 falcata, and that means 19-20 x3.

 

[19,100] Quarterstaff of Vaulting: it’s a +1/+1 darkwood quarterstaff, but it works like a power pole that can extend and give you +5 on jumping checks. It also has this amazing ability to let you make a DC 25 Acrobatics check to jump over an enemy and get into flanking position.

 

[50,320] Rapier of Puncturing: [expletive]! This weapon gives you a touch attack to do 1d6 Con damage 3/day. That could kill something quickly if it’s taken damage already. Oh, and it’s a +2 wounding rapier.

 

[10,305] Rending Claw Blade [Catfolk]: the catfolk racial weapon that gets rid of your claws status as natural weapons, meaning the fun that you want to have with these is mostly lost. Otherwise it’s still not bad to gain a rend attack with 1.5x STR damage.

 

[20,301] Ricochet Hammer: this weapon was invalidated when the Ricochet Toss feat came out and the throwing options on their own got better.

 

[28,015] Rose Knight’s Blade (Adventurer’s Guide): this weapon seems mediocre at first, being a +1 benevolent mithral longsword, but it has a nice little protection ability against mind-affecting effects that let you re-save or remove the condition from an ally, like a high level spell.

 

[5,312] Runefrost Hatchet (Rise of the Runelords: Anniversary Edition): for being a +1 battleaxe, this thing does not do enough to justify its price. 5 rounds per day of +1d6 negative energy is just not that great, and a DC 12 fortitude save is laughable.

 

[18,235] Sacrificial Sword (Magical Marketplace): up to 3 times you can use this +2 bastard sword to kill someone and transfer their life force into a fallen ally with a Reach Breath of Life effect. This is situational, and seems to be designed for you to kill yourself with it to save an ally.

 

[78,815] Scimitar of the Spellthief: +1 keen heartseeking spellstealing golden freaking scimitar is designed to mess up spellcasters. It also gives you +2 on spellcraft and UMD checks and provides as many Detect Magics on items as you want, but only one at a time. Great utility, and great abilities, on a great weapon.

 

[1,516] Searing/Sizzling Arrow: it’s really expensive for a +1 flaming/corrosive arrow, it does keep burning for 3 rounds, but 4d6 fire/acid is not worth 1,500gp.

 

[4,315] Shatterspike: +1 longsword that is treated as a +4 when you both have Improved Sunder and are currently sundering a weapon that is no higher than +4. Really situational.

 

[26,712] Shatterstone Hammer (Heroes of the Wild): a +1 warhammer that gets better (bane) against [earth] creatures and constructs made from earth or stone. It has some cool sundering ability for rocks I guess?

 

[8,350] Shearing Sword (Inner Sea Combat): this weapon can empower itself 3 times per day for 10 rounds to allow the +1 greatsword to bypass the first 5 points of any DR that isn’t DR/epic. Not a bad find at earlier levels.

 

[18,310] Shieldplitter Lance: keen is kinda wasted on a lance, and shields are not even that widely used when you’re fighting monsters.

 

[12,780] Shifter’s Sorrow: it’s alchemical silver, so there’s a problem right there. If you’re going to fight exclusively shapeshifters then this works, but still it’s a costly +1/+1 two-bladed sword.

 

 

[2,282; 4,057] Slaying Arrow, & Greater: a single +1 arrow with a specific type of enemy keyed to it, like bane. That type of enemy takes an extra 50 points of damage if they fail a DC 20 fort save. That’s not bad, the greater ones deal 100 points of damage for a DC 23 fort save. Great against enemies with low forts, with decent DCs, like casters.

 

[132] Sleep Arrow: DC 11 and nonlethal. I guess if you need to catch a cat or something?

 

[48,502] Spirit Blade: a +3 ghost touch dagger that can also cast Dispel Magic once per day. Useful.

 

[18,830] Steadfast Urumi (Inner Sea Combat): it gives you a deflection bonus, up to +4, neat. +1 mighty cleaving urumi.

 

[4,501] Stirge Dart (Dirty Tactics Toolbox): I’ve found a dancing weapon that does something! Instead of doing normal damage, this weapon functions as a dancing weapon and does 1 point of Constitution damage over 4 turns, then becomes inert. Use them on the boss.

 

[42,816] Summoner’s Sorrow: a +2 cold iron glaive that does an extra 2d6 against summoned creatures (including eidolons). If you hit a summoned creature that can be dispelled, you get to dispel it using your BAB in place of your CL. It can also attempt a dismissal once per day at DC 17.

 

[50,335] Sun Blade: a bastard sword that you treat like a short sword that gets better vs. evil creatures. It does double damage to undead! It also has a sweet Daylight ability.

 

[11,320] Swift Obsidian Axe: Obsidian is a bad material.

 

[25,715] Sword of Life Stealing: +2 longsword that deals a negative level on a crit, and gives you 1d6 temp HP when you do it. I see no drawbacks.

 

[22,315] Sword of the Planes: it’s gonna be a +1 sword most of the time, unless you’re in one of those games that takes you to other planes. It’s decent against outsiders, but I’d rather just get a +4 longsword.

 

[32,350] Sword of Vengeance (Chronicle of the Righteous): a +2 holy greatsword that can holy smite once per day. It has a mediocre blind effect, but otherwise it’s not a bad weapon.

 

[47,315] Sylvan Scimitar: figure out how to always be in a temperate climate, and this weapon grants you the Cleave feat and it does 2d6 instead of just 1.

 

[33,835] Talonstrike Sword (Adventurer’s Guide): a +2 defending bastard sword made from mithral that can cast Dimensional Anchor on a crit. The defending ability also affects your mount, though I wouldn’t use this with a mount.

[14,315] Ten-ring Sword: a +2 martial weapon that has a third ring slot, like the magic items. Amazing. Don’t count on crits.

 

[29,101] Tenacious Atlatl Dart (Ranged Tactics Toolbox): a +1 returning dart that functions like a javelin and automatically attempts a Dispel Magic check if you hit an enemy protected by Abjuration magic. Great utility.

 

[59,700] Thorn Bow (Ranged Tactics Toolbox): a +2 lesser designating composite (STR 3) longbow. It can do wall of thorns once per day. Seems a bit expensive for what it does, but wall of thorns is a good spell.

 

[50,302] Traitor’s Blade (Dirty Tactics Toolbox): a +2 wounding dagger that gets a DC 18 charm monster effect. Look at the price.

 

[18,650] Trident of Fish Command: obligatory Aquaman joke. +1 trident that can try and command sea creatures.

 

[9,815] Trident of Stability: this helps you not get knocked over if you stand on it really weird, and it’s only a +1 trident.

 

[109,665] Trident of the Storm Captain (Blood of the Moon): control weather 1/day is a really strong ability in the right game. I don’t know when you’ll ever have the money for this on hand, but if you get it as random loot, it’s a +4 shock trident. It has extra uses for natural builds if you can shapeshift into something with a bite attack.

 

[10,115] Trident of Warning: a +2 trident that can sense any of the threats around you underwater for a pretty decent range. Niche item, but cool.

 

[15,065] Triton’s Trident: +1 monstrous humanoid-bane trident. It gets hydraulic push 3/day or hydraulic torrent 1/day. Find something better.

 

[23,310] Undercutting Axe: a +1 giant bane battleaxe that has a great ability once per day, it can deal 11 points of STR damage. That means they drop their modifier by 5/6, like gaining +5/6 AC against that monster, or reducing its overall damage. It lasts 7 rounds, and still does half on a successful DC 16 save which means it’s not useless.

 

[41,335] Valor’s Minion: you’re not a paladin, but if you take the VMC cavalier stuff, you can use an extra challenge to treat yourself as 3 levels higher, which may improve your to-hit or AC and it gives you an extra 3 damage per hit. A bit pricey, but it is a +2 holy bastard sword.

 

[20,315] Valorous Blade (Weapon Master’s Handbook): +1 valiant scimitar, so you gotta have the cavalier stuff, once per day you can give your allies a +2 morale on some stuff. There are better and less expensive ways to do this.

[28,550] Vaultbow (Inner Sea Temples): if you worship Abadar, and have the Rapid Reload feat, then this +1 light repeating crossbow becomes not useless. Well, less useless. It has an extradimensioal space that functions as a magazine that holds 20 bolts, and thrice per day you can bust out a chain to entangle someone. Cool?

 

[21,820] Vengeance’s Edge (Adventurer’s Guide): I don’t like this weapon, unless you’re immune to fire and have gp to waste. It’s a +2 countering impervious dueling sword, that has an ability when it gets… destroyed or sundered; which it is designed to prevent… Then it drops a 10d6 not fireball with a crappy 14 DC.

 

[95,318] Void Scythe: +1 brilliant energy scythe that isn’t so brilliant. It’s the opposite of that cuz it’s dark! If you’re considering this weapon, don’t, it’s for evil clerics or clerics that channel negative energy and waste proficiency on scythes. Bestowing negative levels is awesome, but unless you built for channeling negative energy (you didn’t) then skip this.

 

[7,812] Wanderer’s Scarf (Inner Sea Combat): a +1 bladed scarf that gives you hide from undead that is useless against intelligent undead. For the price, it isn’t bad for a utility item in an undead heavy game.

 

[10,310] War Lance (Knights of the Inner Sea): what a useless magic item that does something you can already do without it…. wait, it’s a +3 lance that only costs 10k? WTF!?!?!?!?!?!? BUY THIS!!!!!!

 

[61,375] Warbringer: this +3 keen vicious falchion has the ability to grant you a free round of rage, even if you aren’t a barbarian, but only on a crit. But it’s a keen falchion, so that will be often. It also has a weak murderous command ability (DC 14 Will) that triggers when you crit as well. It doesn’t say that you get to skip the fatigued condition when the one round of rage wears off, so I’d be hard pressed not to say this is meant for barbarians. It is awesome though.

 

[26,380] Wasp’s Kiss (Inner Sea Combat): a +1 heartseeker elven curve blade that is designed for characters who want to use poisons. It can hold doses of poison, increases their frequency, reduces their save against the poison, the works. If you wanna use poison, this is the melee weapon for you.

 

 

 

Magic Armor

Overall, you can expect a lot of these to be secondary or tertiary priorities as far as your money goes, most of the time there isn’t much to improve your armor with at earlier levels until you get your armor to +5. Other than genuinely improving your AC, you’ll be looking at different kinds of utility options to improve your narrative power. You don't have a Warrior Spirit like ability for this, but there is Master Armorer, which allows you to craft your own sets of armor. I would consider this option if you really plan on maxing out what your armor can do, otherwise this could get really expensive. Shields however, are another animal and there’s plenty of added options that make shields unique items to build for, including options that can improve their functionality as weapons.

+1 Abilities

[heavy] Advancing (Armor Master’s Handbook): you will most likely benefit from heavy armor. Heavy armor melee guys will love this, it’s fantastic and it helps you get around the movement problem elegantly.

 

[shield] Arrow Catching: this one’s kinda weird. It gives you a +1 deflection bonus against ranged attacks, which is pretty cool, but it’s overall worse than just investing in a ring. You can divert arrows to hit your AC instead of your allies. This is a decent way to tank for your allies, as long as they stay within 5 feet of you. It’s a must for power turtles who want to help the party.

 

[shield] Assiduous (Armor Master’s Handbook): if you ever think you might go against gaze attacks, then take this. If you ever get to use it, you’ll never regret the money.

 

[medium] Balanced (Armor Master’s Handbook): I actually love this, its an immediate action that transfers some of your enhancement bonus to a single type of saving throw. My money says investing in Will saves is your best bet here, but a case can be made for Reflex. This needs to be placed on medium armor, but there are ways around that with special materials and feats and whatnot.

 

[light or medium] Balanced (Ultimate Equipment): if falling down is your greatest fear ever, this helps you against attempts to trip or knock you down. It also helps in environments to maintain your balance with a +4, which means the base save (DC 5) you’ll pass automatically. You may be better off with taking a different option to just train Acrobatics properly, but this is a decent alternative.

 

[light or heavy shields] Bashing: up your damage dice by 2 steps, and treat it as a +1 weapon. Figure out from your DM if that makes it a +1 weapon for enchanting, but it would make it a viable option if it did.

 

[armor] Benevolent: if you are making the Aid Another build, or are looking to equip a Protector familiar with something, this ability is where it’s at. Otherwise, skip it.

 

[armor] Bitter: DC 14 fort sucks, don’t bother reading it.

 

[shield] Blinding: DC 14 Reflex save. Since Reflex is supposedly the worst save, you could use this for a while before it becomes useless. Blinded is a great debuff.

 

[armor] Bolstering: if you get hit by an enemy or BBEG, you’ll get +2 on saves vs them for the rest of their turn. If you’re feeling a bit weak on saves, this isn’t as bad as it seems, given the duration. A lot of abilities require you to be hit before they trigger, so a +2 on those could be beneficial.

 

[armor] Calming: this seems like it's useful, but it only works on enemies who have rage, and at that a DC 15 Will won’t be effective.

 

[armor] Champion: this is listed solely for the fact that I’ve already mentioned VMC cavalier as a good choice, this gives you an extra +2 sacred bonus on AC when using smite/challenge. Sacred stacks with your enhancement bonuses and it applies to touch.

[shield] Clangorous: not worth the money, the DCs are garbage.

 

[armor] Crusading (Advanced Class Origins): this is actually better than the Champion ability, but it does require you invest into the ability to get Lay on Hands, which may be off limits to you otherwise. Still worth mentioning since +2 sacred bonus to AC is an amazing buff for a +1 ability.

 

[armor] Dastard: Champion ability for evil characters, nice.

 

[armor] Deathless: campaign dependent, this is useful almost exclusively against undead or evil clerics. Good thing for us they happen to cover a lot of common enemies. Still, this is campaign dependent, but if you are in any way considering it based on the game you’re playing, then you won't regret it.

 

Defiant: bane backwards. You can actually increase your enhancement bonus on your armor up to +7 with this, but you have to pick the exact enemy to use this against and you have to invest in +5 armor first. You probably won’t get enough mileage from this unless you’re in a specific game where one type of enemy is expected.

 

 

[armor] Evolving (Melee Tactics Toolbox): so, the armor melds into you reducing your AC. Bad start, but for 30 minutes it can give you a bunch of utility like abilities from the Summoner’s Evolution list. Stuff like improved natural armor seems completely pointless, but gaining a swim speed and gills while merging your big heavy full plate into your body may not be outside the realm of useful. Scent is also really useful for tracking down enemies etc. Consider it for out of combat applications.

 

[shield] Folding (Armor Master’s Handbook): I love this actually, for builds that don’t know whether they want to invest in one combat style vs. another. You can change your shield into any other kind of shield. I guess you can get metal tower shields this way, neat. You can also potentially mix and match different shield abilities, and change into something you could use on a two-handed weapon.

 

Light Fortification: 25% chance to negate a crit or a sneak attack. The odds are low, but the effect is good. If you’re considering spending the money, it may be better for you to go with the better versions though, that said you’ll never feel bad about having this, unless you roll a variable in that in-between range.

 

Frosted (Melee Tactics Toolbox): this helps you get out of grapples, and does damage to things that constrict, pin, or eat you. As long as they aren’t immune to cold. Could be worse, but it could be better too.

 

Grinding: this works better as a defense for grapples, they take damage every single attempt they make, and this counts as armor spikes on your turn, using your armor’s enhancement bonus for the weapon damage. Not bad.

[heavy or tower shields] Heraldic (Armor Master’s Handbook): you can treat your shield as a holy symbol or a banner if you somehow got one of those class features….

 

Impervious: you won't know how much this is worth until you need it. Like the weapon ability, this works great against opposed sunder attempts and helps out against oozes and rust attacks.

 

[metallic armor or shield] Mirrored: if you think you’re going up against gaze attacks often this can help, maybe? Probably not.

 

[armor] Poisoning (Magical Marketplace): if you’re one of those builds that’s all about making poison work, this is a must. That role however, is most likely going to another class. It’s here in case that one ratfolk build cares about it, which they most likely do not.

 

[shield] Ramming: if and when you make a charge attack with the intention of using your shield bash attack, you get to use the armor’s enhancement bonus in place of the already existing (if any) weapon enhancement bonus. Very situational, and I wouldn’t bother with it unless you plan on exclusively charging with your shield as your entire character build.

 

[shield] Rebounding (Magical Marketplace): you’ll get an extra +2 AC against thrown weapons, which are exactly how common? It can do extra stuff against alchemists. Meh.

 

[shield] Singing (Melee Tactics Toolbox): you can counter bardic abilities, essentially giving you 10 rounds of countersong per day with a +10 for the d20 check. Doesn’t seem that bad if you’re in a game where Countersong is something you could use and don't have a bard, which is very unlikely anyway.

 

[armor] Spell Storing: you can have up to a 3rd level touch spell that will discharge as an immediate action when someone hits or touches you. There may be some interesting uses for this, but they all rely on you having spellcaster buddies willing to put their spells into this thing.

 

[shield] Spellrending (Armor Master’s Handbook): I really want this to be good, but paying for that SR on your shield really isn’t worth it because it’s not that great for the price.

 

Spellsink (Dirty Tactics Toolbox): I think I’m gonna cry a little. This ability is so good, it makes me want to make it purple just on principle, however for the ability to work, the enemy has to fail a meager 14 Will save, and it only works once per day.

 

[armor] Stanching: this is great if you think you’re going to be facing Bleed effects often enough. It also has this nice ability to add it’s enhancement bonus on checks to stabilize when dying, a scenario you do not want to plan around.

 

 

[medium] Terrain-Striding (Armor Master’s Handbook): pick a favored terrain, you gain a +10ft enhancement bonus to movespeed and ignore the ACP on a bunch of skills in that terrain. Some games take place almost entirely in a single terrain. Consider this if you’re in one of those games, or if there’s one that is predominant where you fight, like in cities or underground, etc.

 

[armor] Vouchsafing: the only time you can use it is when you can do nothing.

 

[armor] Warding: plan to face a lot of paladins, antipaladins, hellknights, inquisitors, or cavaliers? This can force resource drain on them, and can even be bolstered if you went with the VMC cavalier build. Consider it then and in games where these types of enemies are very common.

 

[medium] Withstanding (Armor Master’s Handbook): it’s like defiant, but it gives you moderate fortification against that type of enemy. Bonus, it also gives you a +2 on knowledge checks to identify them. If you’re in a game where defiant is a good choice, so is this.

+2 Abilities

[heavy] Adamant (Armor Master’s Handbook): you can turn your armor into effectively having Adamantine armor for 9 rounds. DR 3/- is low, and I’d rather build around better DR. By the time you can afford this, it’s nigh useless.

 

[shield] Animated: this functions well for anyone who plans on using two hands. You’ll get 4 rounds of a shield that follows you around and can keep using passive abilities. A must for anyone planning on using a shield with a two-handed weapon that doesn’t wanna waste feats.

 

[shield] Arrow Deflection: you get Deflect Arrows on your shield. You gotta make a DC 20 Reflex to do it, but that might not be a problem on some builds. Still, it’s only once per round and only blocks one attack. Seems weak for +2.

 

[light or medium] Bloodthirsty (Agents of Evil): it’s a 2 for 1 exchange on improving your enhancement bonus; unless you picked up rage, it’s not worth it.

 

[armor] Ghost Spike (Dirty Tactics Toolbox): you get to add +1 ghost touch armor spikes to your armor for up to 1 minute, once per day. I’d rather just invest in them.

 

Jarring: Dazed is such a good debuff, and the activation time is right, and you even get 3 of them per day. But that 16 Fort save will not serve you well.

 

[shield] Mastering (Armor Master’s Handbook): if you ever wanted to use a shield in conjunction with TWF, this ability lets you treat your shield as if it was the same weapon for the purpose of using your weapon group for damage. If you’re already using the close weapon group, then you can use Weapon Focus/Specialization and their Greater versions on your shield if you already have them for another weapon. This is great for sword and board, and it’s a fighter exclusive thing. Even if you aren't using the shield as a primary weapon, you can use it like it is in a pinch.

 

[shield] Merging: just why? Why? Trap option, don't even waste the time to read it.
